newsitem.title: BELGIUM: Commission clears non-military parts of BAE/Lagardere deal.
newsitem.headline: Commission clears non-military parts of BAE/Lagardere deal.

text.p: The European Commission said on Tuesday it had cleared under competition rules the non-military aspects of the missiles joint venture between British Aerospace Plc (BAe) and France's Lagardere.
The military aspects of the deal will be decided by France and Britain.

The Commission said the areas cleared concerned precision optical engineering; robotic control units; space system structures, meachanisms and aerials; environmental and electromagnetic testing; and electronics and microelectronics applications.

BAe and Lagardere announced in August they were creating a joint venture called Matra BAe Dynamics that would have an annual turnover of around one billion pounds ($645 million) and employ 6,000 people in Britain and France.
The companies only submitted the civilian aspects of the deal to EU clearance following instructions from the British and French governments.

The Commission said in a statement it had cleared the aspects concerned because the combined market share of the two parent companies was "low" and that therefore the deal would not create or strengthen a dominant position within the European Union.
Under EU rules, national governments may refrain from disclosing information on the production or trade in war material if deemed necessary to protect the essential interests of their security.

In May, the Commission also only approved the non-military aspects of a sonar joint venture between Britain's General Electric Company Plc and Thomson-CSF SA of France following similar government instructions.
